event.doc_name: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

evidence.text: a. Certify the action as a class action pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 23 and appoint Plaintiffs and Oliver Law Group PC as class representatives and class counsel respectively
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff: Certify class action under Fed. R. Civ. P. 23

evidence.text: b. Adjudge and declare that the acts, omissions, policies, and practices of Defendants... are in violation of the rights of the Plaintiffs under the Cruel and Unusual Punishments Clause of the Eighth Amendment
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff: Declare Defendants' actions violate Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments

evidence.text: c. Issue a judgment against Defendants in an amount to be determined at trial, including compensatory and punitive damages
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff: Issue judgment including compensatory and punitive damages

evidence.text: d. Award Plaintiffs the costs of this suit, and reasonable attorneys' fees and litigation expenses pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 1988
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff: Award costs and attorneys' fees

evidence.text: e. Retain jurisdiction of this case until Defendants have fully complied with the orders of this Court
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff: Retain jurisdiction until full compliance

evidence.text: f. Grant Plaintiffs such other relief as the Court deems appropriate and just
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint and Demand for Jury Trial

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff: Other relief as court deems appropriate

event.doc_name: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

evidence.text: The Eighth Amendment of the United States Constitution prohibits the infliction of cruel and unusual punishment and is violated when prison officials create, allow and fail to protect against prison-related violence and when prison conditions fail to meet basic human needs.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: Eighth Amendment

evidence.text: The Eighth Amendment of the United States Constitution prohibits the infliction of cruel and unusual punishment and is violated when prison officials create, allow and fail to protect against prison-related violence and when prison conditions fail to meet basic human needs.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: Fourteenth Amendment

evidence.text: Parchman is so severely underfunded and staffed with persons such as Defendants herein, that inmates are routinely denied access to basic amenities such as clean water, plumbing, and electricity. A slew of disturbing images and videos have surfaced showing that inmates are being required to defecate in plastic bags inside of their cells because their toilets are not functional.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

evidence.text: Inmates have resorted to setting fires to compel officials to enter their building and hopefully render life-saving care to fellow inmates who are sick and dying or to save themselves from violence.
evidence.source_document: Fifth Amended Complaint and Jury Demand

add_extracted.value: Conditions at Mississippi State Penitentiary at Parchman include flooding, lack of running water and electricity, black mold, rats and mice infestation, non-functional toilets requiring inmates to defecate in plastic bags, and dangerous environments leading to inmate deaths and escapes.

evidence.text: MOTION to Certify Class by Andrew Alexander, Hubert Anderson, John Barnes, Steven Barnes, Jarred Baysinger, Maurice Bishop, Benny Blansett DO NOT FILE, Jason Bonds, Antonio Boyd, McKinley Brady, Darkeyus Brown, Christopher Burns, Cedric Calhoun, Rayshon Darden.
